document.title: 2024 Indiana Content Connectors: Earth and Space Science

6B9C48954334400CA81F4E5C5FEBD431.description:
Use representations to illustrate how the relationships
among Earth systems are changed by human activities. An example of
the impacts from human activity is how an increase in atmospheric
carbon dioxide results in an increase in photosynthetic biomass on
land and an increase in ocean acidification, with resulting impacts on
sea organism health and marine populations.

752F632D029C48228F25459A046130D4.description:
Use evidence from data and global climate models to
predict the future impact of global or regional climate change on
Earth systems. (E)

E20B1BC399A8482C814F98E9A065D922.description:
Evaluate or refine technological solutions by
comparing how each solution addresses the impact of human
activity on natural systems. Examples for limiting future impacts
could range from local efforts (such as reducing, reusing, and
recycling resources) to large-scale geoengineering design solutions
(such as altering global temperatures by making large changes to
the atmosphere or ocean).

BCBCD3E7DE2047539849487F46C2C9DD.description:
Use data to describe the relationships among
management of natural resources, the sustainability of human
populations, and biodiversity.

4EDA4C53F26B4287825BE6E4A3902489.description:
Compare cost-benefit ratios of design solutions for
developing, managing, and utilizing energy and mineral resources.

04F4707FFA7E457FBA07A5A543689679.description:
Use evidence to describe relationships between human
activity and the availability of natural resources, occurrence of natural
hazards, or changes in climate. (E)

E396222F2C174C9A83C4DAA96AE25DE2.description:
Use evidence to support claims related to the
coevolution of Earth's systems and life on Earth.

704EB5D394CF4FA7A027CB2CA4E36CAB.description:
Create a model to describe the cycling of carbon
among the hydrosphere, atmosphere, geosphere, and biosphere.

14C861061AB84FF191F6155D974654B9.description:
Use evidence to describe the properties of water and
the effects of water on Earth materials and surface processes. (E)

5E0E367B2E804C378A028F71A7314DC5.description:
Use a model to describe how variations in the Earth's
orbit and tilt affects climate on a very long-term scale.

ED886907DDD245E89AC7221D07BE927B.description:
Explain that seismic waves and their reflection are
used to learn about the structure of the Earth. [Clarification
Statement: Emphasis is on both a one-dimensional model of Earth,
with radial layers determined by density, and a three-dimensional
model, which is controlled by mantle convection and the resulting
plate tectonics. Examples of evidence include maps of Earth’s
three-dimensional structure obtained from seismic waves, records of
the rate of change of Earth’s magnetic field (as constraints on
convection in the outer core), and identification of the composition of Earth’s layers from high-pressure laboratory experiments.]

120A7B2F1F3D477E83A65D1106B12B96.description:
Use a model to illustrate how radioactive decay
functions as the primary source of heat within Earth's crust, driving
thermal convection.

9F484F2AE71B412EB657FCCE63C530C2.description:
Use a model of Earth to describe that the motion of
the mantle and its plates occurs primarily through thermal
convection.

2CA141128B454B3D9D47C70D06C12800.description:
Use geoscience data to support the claim that Earth's
systems are interconnected, illustrating how changes to Earth's
surface can result in feedbacks to other Earth systems. (E)

EB8C1D10EF9A4BCBB37142425D976A3B.description:
Use a model to compare the impact of Earth's internal
and surface processes at various scales and timeframes on the
formation of continental and ocean-floor features.

AEB53131839E475293BE2281C78994AD.description:
Use evidence to explain how objects in the solar system
can provide information about Earth’s formation and early history. (E)

E5C13437969A457988D47518A69F9576.description:
Use evidence to describe how the movements of rocks
at Earth's surface over time (i.e., plate tectonics) explains the ages of
continental and oceanic crustal rocks. (E)

472070A66E424BCB82DD6BD4E818B447.description:
Use a representation to predict a change in orbits due to
various effects (e.g., gravitational effects from, or collisions with, other
objects).

6C49A5EB6A7842DFB409FE796B305F91.description:
Explain that some orbiting objects move in an elliptical
pattern around the sun.

D595F3C7A5BA4206BC92ABB140B75D35.description:
Use evidence to explain the chemical processes over
stars' life cycles that produce elements.

63EBCF5B162F46A093CDD423BE067222.description:
Use evidence (e.g., red shift of light from galaxies,
cosmic microwave background, observed composition of ordinary
matter) to support the Big Bang theory.

14BACCBAB9CF4E2799E3104E04FC4C4A.description:
Use a model to describe how energy generated by the
sun is transferred to the Earth through radiation. (E)

6B7FC392F4454667885F2A1AC87B5C25.description:
Explain that the sun has a life span, which means that it
is changing and will eventually burn out. (E)

EC6FC941B11E4751B69E75496218AAD7.description: From Molecules to Organisms: Structures and Processes
